MainHeading.Title: Health Contributions Bill, 1978: Committee and Final Stages.
MainHeading.P: SECTION 1.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Haughey) Minister for Health (Mr. Haughey)
Speaker.P: I move amendment No. 1:
In page 3, line 18, after “Income Tax Act, 1967,” to insert “but without regard to section 192 of that Act,”.

On further consideration of the text of the Bill, it transpires that this amendment is necessary. The purpose of the amendment is to ensure that the incomes of a man and his wife are treated separately for the purposes of this legislation. If we did not make this change, then under the income tax legislation concerned the income of the husband and wife would be treated as one.
I have not been circulated with a copy of this amendment, possibly because of the postal difficulties to which reference was made earlier.
It is on the Order Paper.
The Minister explained that a husband and wife having separate incomes would have the health contribution rated separately.
Yes. For the purpose of this legislation they would be treated as separate people with separate incomes.
For the purpose of the Income Tax Act they are treated collectively.
Under the Income Tax Act the income of the wife is treated as the income of the husband, generally speaking.

There is provision in this Bill that any person earning over £5,000 a year, though the Minister has power to amend that figure, would pay £50 and anyone earning less than £5,000 would pay 1 per cent. By virtue of this amendment, which arrived this morning and which has not been referred to in any previous discussions on the Bill, the Minister now proposes to raise a separate levy on separate income earners if both husband and wife are earning. Surely this is imposing additional taxation upon a couple who are both in employment. It would seem to be a progression of the campaign by the Minister for Finance against well-heeled and articulate women.

It was always intended that a man and a wife would be treated separately in this context and I made this clear at the outset. The Bill as drafted did not make that specifically clear and I want to do so now. I made it clear that a man and a wife with separate incomes would be separately liable for health contributions and separately eligible for benefits. The whole philosophy of this legislation is that one pays a contribution and that is related to eligibility. It was the intention from the outset that a man and a wife with separate incomes would be liable for separate contributions and eligible for services in their own right.

Does this mean that a husband and wife each earning £5,600 must both pay? Who pays for the children? Shall we attach the benefits of the male children to the father and the benefits of the female children to the mother? This is a very serious problem. If a wife is not working, the husband's contributions cover benefits for his wife and his children. That is provided for in the Bill. If the wife becomes a wage earner and has an income over £5,600, she pays £50 for herself. There is an element of discrimination. Whose payment provides benefits for the children?

This Bill is in line with modern thinking in regard to men and women. There is no discrimination. It was made clear from the outset that every income earner would be treated separately for the purposes of this legislation. It will apply to everyone over 16 years of age. Unfortunately the age must be 16 because that is the social welfare qualifying age. Everybody over 16 years of age will be liable for health contributions. The question as to whom the children will be related for purposes of eligibility will be decided when we publish the regulations. I have an open mind on that matter as yet and it is still under consideration. If both parents are wage earners and liable for contributions, the best interests of the children will be taken into consideration in deciding which parent will bring the children in the wake, as it were, for eligibility purposes.

If a man is earning £11,000 a year the maximum amount he pays is £50. If two incomes of £5,500 are coming into the household, the contribution from that household will be £100. There is an element of unfairness there. Will the male children be attached to the father and the female children attached to the mother?

No. I have made the position absolutely clear. It was clearly stipulated at the outset that every income earner would be liable for a health contribution. I do not think Deputy O'Connell can argue that he is on the side of the feminists when he suggests that we are wrong in departing from the income tax principle whereby a wife's income is considered as part of her husband's income. In this legislation we are treating men and women separately, whether married or single. Each will be treated as an income earner where that is the case and will be liable to pay the contribution.

All persons over 16 will be brought within the compass of the legislation. Those under 16 or other dependants will be related, for eligibility purposes, to one or other, or both of the parents. That is a matter which is under consideration. I am examining the position to see what is the best thing to do in the interests of the children or other dependants. That does not arise under this Bill; that will be dealt with by the regulations which will be made under the Health Act, 1970. The Deputy will be afforded an opportunity of going into that at that stage.
The Minister always may have had in the devious corridors of his mind the intention of raising this health taxation on both husband and wife separately if they were earning——
This is not taxation, this is a health contribution.
But it was never before alluded to.
It certainly was. Any time I was asked the question I answered clearly and specifically.

Not in the euphoric press conference, nor indeed in the Bill or in the explanatory memorandum. Several points arise straightaway in relation to this. I identified during the Second Stage debate very clearly that people earning over £5,000 a year would not get the same amount of insurance cover as people earning under that figure. For instance, a man earning over £5,000 a year would still be liable to pay consultants' fees and would still be liable to pay the fees for maternity services in respect of his spouse. What would be the position now?
Only consultancy fees for maternity.

What would be the position now—if that man is earning over £5,000 a year, his wife is earning less than £5,000 a year, and they are both being asked to pay the health contribution separately—will the wife be eligible for cover for all hospital costs, including consultants' fees, and the husband will not be? In a case like that to whom is the responsibility for the issue to be assigned? Will they be covered under the wife's complete cover for maintenance and treatment costs or will they be covered merely under the husband's cover which would still render him in a position in which he would be liable to pay consultants' costs in respect of children? I should have thought that in legislation, in general, the responsibility for the children would have been assigned to the father rather than to the mother.
That might not necessarily be to their advantage.

Certainly it would not be in the case I have just outlined. Surely this single line amendment ought to have been dealt with more extensively further on within the Bill by dealing with this very situation. I must admit that I had no comprehension that the husband and wife who are both earning would be made pay separately.
The position is made clear in the explanatory memorandum. The Deputy need not be acting all this innocence. The Deputy made a false statement a moment ago.
Wait now, may I make the point?
I will call the Deputy again.
I had not finished.
The Minister is entitled to intervene on a point of explanation.

The Deputy made a specific statement that this was not dealt with in the explanatory memorandum. The Deputy should read the document. He should read what I say about these things. It is quite clearly and specifically set out in the explanatory memorandum. Paragraph 2 on the first page of the explanatory memorandum says:
Under the new arrangements all individuals over 16 years of age with an income will, with certain exceptions, be obliged to pay health contributions.
Nothing could be more specific than that—individuals.

Of course I read the explanatory memorandum. Of course I do not accept the allegations about false statements. It seems to be a favourite ploy on that side of the House now, whenever one is embarrassed, to decide that the other person has made false statements. Incidentally in this case the explanatory memorandum is not much more illuminating than the Bill itself because much of it is merely repetition of the wording of the Bill. The explanatory memorandum says:

MainHeading.P: Under the new arrangements all individuals over 16 years of age with an income will, with certain exceptions, be obliged to pay health contributions.
It could reasonably have been thought—and I certainly thought—that those exceptions would apply to a family where both husband and wife were earning.

Speaker.P: Nonsense.

It is a long way away from the Minister's allegation of false statements. Under existing VHI arrangements a husband and wife with no children are covered for all public ward hospital costs for a net expenditure of £59.20 after claiming income tax at standard rate. I asked during the Second Stage debate if these health contributions would be allowable against income tax. I do not think the Minister dealt with that in his reply. If they are not, then in a situation in which husband and wife, without issue, are earning over £5,000 a year each, they will be paying now £100 a year between the two of them. They will not be able to claim it for income tax. As opposed to being insured totally for £59.20 with the VHI, now they are going to discover that they will still not be covered, having paid the £100—because they are both earning over £5,000—for consultants' costs. On Second Stage when we were dealing with the people who gained and those who lost under this Bill—and I endeavoured fairly to point out the people whom I felt had gained under the Minister's Bill as well as those, in particular manual workers earning over £5,000, whom I felt had lost—I did not deal with this category. Certainly this is another category of person who has lost entirely. They will be paying almost twice as much as they were paying to the VHI. They will discover also that they are not covered for consultants' fees which they would have been under the VHI scheme for an expenditure of £59.20 after tax.

MainHeading.P: The same sort of calculations could be made in respect of a husband earning over £5,000 and a wife earning less than that figure. I am not sure at what stage—because I have not done the exercise—the cut-off point would be. It is quite clear to me now that the majority of couples who are both earning will find themselves paying far more into the State scheme. And if one of them is earning over £5,000 that person will be under the obligation still to cover himself or herself for consultants' fees. Therefore, such people will find themselves in a position in which it will cost them more to pay into the State scheme and cover themselves for some of their consultant's fees with the VHI scheme than it does at present. It would have been far better had the Minister made that clearer from the beginning. No amount of blustering on his part will change the situation now. I am quite certain I am not the only one who has been led astray in this connection.

Speaker.P: There are very serious implications in this. I think we have honestly been misinformed on this Bill. These are the most serious implications I have ever encountered in any Bill coming before us. I will tell the House why. The Minister is going to make regulations. We have to take the case of a husband and wife both earning money. If the wife is earning under £5,000 and the husband over that figure—£5,500 as is said—I want to know to whom are the children attached with regard to benefits because this is the most serious aspect of the Bill.
I have already answered that question.
No, the Minister has not.
I will answer again if the Deputy will permit me.

I will give the Minister the reasons I want to know. If it is decided that the children, for benefit purposes, are attached to the mother's earnings of under £5,000, they get free hospitalisation, including maintenance and consultants' fees. If they are attached to the father's earnings, over the figure of £5,500, they do not get anything; they do not get the consultants' fees, they do not get out-patient services free. We are making sure we are not discriminating against women. There is a great tendency to say that we are not when women have to pay. When they are entitled to benefits it is one thing, but when they are paying there is no discrimination; we let them be equal.

This is a case in point. There is a very serious problem posed here. To whom will the children be attached for the purposes of benefit? It is a very serious matter. If they are attached to the mother and her earnings are under £5,000 per annum it could make an awful lot of difference. If they are attached to the father they will have to pay for everything if his income is over £5,500 per annum. That is the most serious implication of this Bill. The Minister is not spelling it out exactly. He says that he will make up his mind about that in the regulations. But this has very serious implications. It could mean a great difference to what their entitlements are in the case of husband and wife both working, one earning less than £5,500 a year and the other earning more than £5,500 a year. If the Minister would say that he will make a decision that the benefits to the children will be attached to the person earning the lower income then he may help to solve the problem. The other aspect of it is that they are now paying double what was intended. The whole Bill becomes a sham and a farce with the couple now paying £2 a week instead of £1 a week whereas if there was one income earner with the same amount of money he would be paying only half the amount from his household. That is a very serious problem and one that was not made clear to us on the Second Stage of the Bill.

On the contrary, this was made perfectly clear on Second Stage. Deputies should really follow what is happening in the House. I quote from my Second Reading speech “Under the Bill now before the House liability for payment of health contributions will extend to all individuals over 16 years of age who have an income”. Could anything be more specific than that? Any time I was asked by trade union delegations or by newspaper men or by anybody else I made it absolutely clear that a man and his wife would be treated separately, as individuals, for health contributions legislation.
Explain the position of the children.

Deputy O'Connell cannot try to ride two horses in this matter. If he is, as I am, in favour of the abolition of all discrimination against women in any shape or form whether they are married or single, he must go along with me in what I am doing in this legislation. To say that a married woman is a person in her own right as far as this legislation is concerned means that she pays her contribution and she gets her eligibility as a separate income earner. There is no argument to that.
Except that one does not have children by the mother and children by the father.

Give me time. I will deal with the children in a moment. Every person over 16 years of age is also treated as an individual for the purpose of this legislation. This legislation deals only with the contributions. I will be making regulations later, before the 1st of April, which will deal with eligibility. Those regulations will have to come before this House positively. They will not be the sort of regulations that go by default unless somebody moves to annul them. I will have to come here and propose these regulations. At that point Deputies O'Connell and Boland will have ample opportunity to go into the eligibility side of things. I said to Deputies O'Connell and Boland that as of now I am considering and examining what the situation of children will be in their interests. I want to make sure that whatever eligibility regulations we apply to children will be to the children's advantage. Will Deputy O'Connell accept that?
Most certainly.

In doing this by regulations I am seeking to work out whatever system will in all circumstances, be to the best advantage of the children, but when I come here with this proposal the House will have an opportunity to go into it further.
Is section 4 of this Bill not particularly relevant to the problem?

There is a certain advantage in treating husband and wife separately. If they are both working all free hospitalisation entitlements stop at £5,000. After that they get free hospitalisation but they must pay the consultant. It there are two people working and they are not treated separately then their wages would need to be very small before they would be covered, because it would be very easy for any two people working to earn over £5,000 between them. Therefore they would have to have voluntary health insurance to cover consultants' fees the same as an individual person earning over £5,000.

If my interpretation of the Bill is correct this Bill means that more people will be eligible to go into what we call the lower to middle income group and will have to have voluntary health insurance to cover the fees of their consultants. This applies if they are treated individually. If they are treated jointly where there are two workers I can see very few people needing to have voluntary health insurance to cover consultants' fees. But the question is to whom are the children attached for the purposes of benefits? I would ask the Minister to let them be attached to the lower income earner, but I certainly agree with treating husband and wife as individuals.

I would like to ask the Minister just one more question in regard to the self-employed person. Take for instance a person who has a valuation of £60 and who has a wife with a £20 valuation. Will such people be treated as being above the £5,000 bracket? I assume that they will be treated the same as people with two separate incomes and will pay two separate contributions.

There must be an income before contributions are payable.

Reckonable earnings relate to those people in the PAYE classes who are insured under the Social Welfare Acts. Emoluments other than reckonable earnings cover persons who come under PAYE but who are not insured, and reckonable incomes other than emoluments will apply to everybody else, including farmers, self-employed people, and company directors. Proprietary directors in receipt of fees will come under section 6. Everybody is covered in some way or another. It is complicated, but sections 5, 6, and 7 take in every body.

I am talking about people who might be classed as dependent relatives, living in family homes and being given small amounts of money to support them.
That would not be taxable and therefore would not attract health contributions.
I appreciate that, broadly speaking, sections 5, 6 and 7 cover most categories in the community who have incomes of one sort or another, but there might be other circumstances.

Will the Deputy accept my word that if there is no assessable income there will be no health contributions chargeable? Section 4 makes it clear that payment of contributions will be subject to the Act and regulations made under the Act.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the available information and statistics on participation ratios in third-level education in Ireland, and in each other EEC country; if he will make a statement on the relatively low level of participation in third-level education in Ireland; and if he is aware of the statements in the HEA report entitled Observations of the Higher Education Authority on Paragraph 7.33 in the Green Paper: Development for FullEmployment which states in page 2 that, of all the EEC countries, Ireland has the lowest percentage of students in higher education; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Information in regard to enrolment numbers in third-level educational institutions in the EEC countries and demographic statistics by age-groups is made available in the following publications: Enrolment Data: Eurostat Education statistics 1970-1975. Population Data: Eurostat Demographic Statistics 1970-1976. These publications are issued by the Office for Official Publications of the European Communities.

In this connection I should emphasise that in drawing conclusions from statistical comparisons of enrolments in different countries it is necessary to have regard to factors which make it difficult to express such comparisons in terms which truly reflect the situation. In so far as Ireland is concerned the early age of admission to third-level educational institutions and the relatively low percentage of students of 24 years of age and upwards are features which, inter alia, should be borne in mind.

I would be concerned that the statement of the Higher Education Authority referred to in the question from the Deputy may give a misleading impression of the situation in Ireland in relation to access to and participation in education at third level.

I may add that I do not consider that an approach based on an attempted comparison of international statistics of enrolments would be a proper basis for policy decisions in the formulation of educational policy for a programme of educational development at third level.

Secondly, does the Minister accept that the evidence in that statement and the implication in the question is that by and large and allowing for the statistical differentials which he referred to there is nevertheless strong evidence to indicate that the percentage of pupils in higher education here is among the lowest in the EEC?

There are two parts in the Deputy's supplementary question. The first is: am I saying that the figures are wrong? What I said is this: It is difficult to compare like with like. For example in Ireland, quite a number of people go into third level at 17 and some even at 16. The relevant figure in the first column of the statistics I mentioned give third-level enrolment as a percentage of the 18-24 population group. For the United Kingdom that is 9.3; for Ireland, 9.2. That does not take into account our 17-year-olds in third-level education whereas there are few if any at 17 years in third level in Britain and practically none on the continent where the normal starting age is about 19. There is another point: when you talk about the percentage of a particular age group in any level you must take cognisance of the percentage that group is of the total population of the particular country. It happens that particular age group in our population is very high as of now. It is not an easy thing to come to a straight conclusion in comparisons.

As the Deputy knows I shall be publishing a White Paper on the whole field of education in 1979. I have plans to develop the National Institute for Higher Education in Dublin and to increase the number of places in the technological sector. I also have forward-going studies in the HEA on the need for third-level education generally in the Dublin area and in the country at large.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Co-Educational Primary School.

Speaker.P: Deputy Horgan has received permission to raise on the adjournment the subject matter of Questions Nos. 11 and 12 on today's Order Paper. Deputy Horgan has not more than 20 minutes.

In Questions Nos. 11 and 12 on today's Order Paper I asked the Minister for Education for a certain amount of information in relation to the proposed new primary education facilities to be provided at Knocknaheeny, Cork. In particular I asked the Minister whether he was aware that the majority of the parents in that area were in favour of a co-educational primary school for their children and if he would take steps to ensure that the parental wishes in this matter were respected. In his answer to this question, or to another one put down in the name of Deputy E. Collins, the Minister gave a certain amount of factual information which had been asked for, and failed completely to address himself to the question of whether he was aware of the educational preferences of the parents in the area and whether he would do anything to ensure that these preferences were built into the kind of school that he and the State are providing for them. I find it very strange that the Minister avoided any mention of this survey because I believe that the evidence upon the basis of which I framed my questions was made available to him in his Department and that copies of the survey and of the relevant findings from the survey were available for his perusal if he had chosen to take them into account.

MainHeading.P: In order to explain the background to the situation I had better say something about the area itself. Knocknaheeny is a new housing area in Cork with a very high proportion of local authority housing. They have an active community association and within that community association they have an education action group. They are also desperately in need of a school. When the question of a school was first mooted, members of the education action group within the community association decided to try to find out from the local community precisely what kind of school the local residents wanted. They went along with a carefully and, may I say, scientifically planned survey, designed to try to elucidate parental preferences about the kind of school. The results of this survey are extremely interesting and to the best of my knowledge have not been challenged by anybody. Approximately one house in three of all the houses in the estate were surveyed at that time and the results of their survey show that almost two-thirds, some 61 per cent of those surveyed, were in favour of a mixed, that is co-educational, school. There was no possibility of misunderstanding the very simple question that was put to the householders involved or of misunderstanding their response to it. They were quite clear in their majority decision in favour of a co-educational school.

The other questions were also of interest. One of them suggested that 90 per cent of the parents wanted a say in the running of their children's school; they already have that to some extent. The other question evoked the information that three-quarters of the parents surveyed were in favour of multi-denominational education, that is children of different religious denominations being educated together. The real point at issue here is whether the people in Knocknaheeny should have the kind of school they want, which is a co-educational school. In order to double-check the veracity of this initial survey the education action group in the association recently carried out another survey in which they surveyed a considerably larger number of houses and asked them again for their opinions about the kind of school they required. At the time they carried out the second survey there were about 650 houses in the estate in question and 500 of those householders, representing about 75 per cent of the whole area, were quite clear and unambiguous in their desire for a co-educational primary school. The other 150 were comprised of people who either could not be contacted, who were not in at the time of the survey, or declined to sign in favour of a co-educational school.

All that the people of Knocknaheeny have been told so far is that they are getting a school and they have been given to understand that the first 16-teacher unit which will be built, while it will naturally have to accommodate both boys and girls, will have accommodation separated by a corridor, some Cork equivalent of the Berlin wall no doubt, for fear that these unfortunate children between the ages of four and 12 should mix together. The people there are extremely upset and angry about the situation because they believe with some justice their very real views in this matter have not been listened to. They have certainly not been listened to by the diocesan authorities who apparently made the initial application for money to build the school. They hoped to have their plea listened to by the Minister and the Department of Education. They have sent the Minister details of the survey and they have asked him to take whatever action is open to him in order to ensure that they have a co-educational primary school.

At the very end of his reply today the Minister addressed himself to the question of whether a co-educational primary school would be built and he said that the question of whether a new school should be organised on a co-educational basis is a matter for local decision. With respect, this begs all the questions that were answered. If it is a matter for local decision, would the Minister say whose local decision is involved? Is it going to be the local decision of the parents or of the diocesan authorities who have put up the initial capital necessary to get this school built? There is a peculiar irony here because there are no local representative structures through which the parents can effectively communicate their wishes and impose them in respect of the kind of school that they are going to have. Of course, there is not even a school management board because this school will be built and operated before the school management board is constituted. All the decisions will have been taken in advance and the parents have to face what is effectively a fait accompli. They not only have to face this fait accompli, they have to pay for it.

In his answer, the Minister gave me the information that the two schools would cost around £760,000. He declined to give me any details regarding the financing of the school buildings, but it is fairly commonly rumoured in Knocknaheeny that the Department will be paying ten-elevenths of the cost of the school buildings which indicates that the local community will be required to pay about one-eleventh. Of course, they will also be required to pay for the site. Even at this initial stage there is enough evidence to suggest that they will be asked for something upwards of £60,000 for the 16-teacher school. The parents are being asked to pay over £60,000 for a school which is not the kind of school they want and they have no effective way —because they have not got £60,000 in their pockets now and because they do not own a site—of ensuring that the school which is being built will match the needs in this regard. Not unnaturally, they have come to the Minister for Education and on their behalf I have asked the Minister for Education what he will do about it. In answer to supplementary questions the Minister said he was quite happy that the decision taken by the Department to go ahead with the building of the school was what the parents wanted. This statement is perfectly defensible, because the parents want a school urgently. However, it ignores one of the fundamental aspects, which is the kind of school they want.

The Minister said he was satisfied that the wishes of the parents and the good of education were being served by the decision taken by his Department. This is evading the issue, because the fundamental decision taken by the Department has nothing to do with whether or not the school is co-educational, but simply with whether there is to be a school there. Of course the parents want a school, and of course it is for the good of education that there should be a school; but the Minister is suppressing one of the fundamental points I am making.

The Minister said later that he had no line one way or the other as to whether the school should be co-educational or not. I said that the parents would be very disappointed that the Minister had no line on this issue. This is not to say that, if the Minister suddenly decided that all our schools should be co-educational, he should rush around the country twisting the arms of parents, management and teachers and forcing them to accept a model imposed from our district. We are saying that there is a dramatically expressed local preference for a co-educational primary school, that the structures to give effect to that local decision do not exist and in the absence of some structures of this kind the parents have come to the Minister and asked him to take action and he is apparently declining to do so.

In response to supplementary questions, the Minister finally said that the people in the area would have the education they want in accordance with their wishes and he assured me that nothing would be left undone in achieving that objective. Can the Minister really stand over that? If the Minister stands over it he will have to make sure that the school provided in Knocknaheeny will be co-educational. Will the Minister tell the House what he now proposes to do to ensure that the primary school in Knocknaheeny will be co-educational?

In the Government's election manifesto the section on education contained a preamble saying that Fianna Fáil recognised the parents as the primary and natural educators and their right to provide education in schools of their choice. If that preamble means anything today, if it is to mean anything to the parents of Knocknaheeny, the Minister will have to come down from the fence on this issue and do what needs to be done to ensure that these parental rights the manifesto talked about become something real and do not remain merely verbiage, which is too common in political statements.

I recognise that there are problems. The structure of our primary education system, despite the widening of participation by parents and teachers in recent years, is still relatively inflexible and there is some difficulty in ensuring that parental wishes are respected in many instances. Here we have a classic case in which a majority of parents, in a given geographical area to be served by a school whose provision has been decided in principle, are looking unambiguously for a certain type of school and apparently cannot get it. It seems to be the situation, that the real choice of school lies not with the parents but with the people who provide money for school sites and for a portion of the building costs. The money for school sites and for a portion of the building costs, is the money of the people, of the parents, and the organisation concerned are basically channels through which that money is brought from the purse and used to help construct the schools. The system is not working in such a way as to deliver the school of their choice to the parents of that city.

One could make an entirely different argument, a theoretical argument, about the issue. One could express one's astonishment that in 1979 it should be thought inappropriate for small boys and girls in the county and city of Cork to be educated together. That argument has already been resolved by the parents; they want their children to be educated together. The initial proposal for a school to serve their area comes from an organisation which apparently does not want to see the children educated together and the people are now looking to the Minister to fill the gap, to take whatever powers are necessary to ensure that their wishes are respected. In the light of the year we are living in, in the light of the Fianna Fáil manifesto and in the light of the Irish Constitution, it is surely not too much to ask.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: I welcome the opportunity to clarify the statement I made today in reply to Questions Nos. 11, 12 and 13 on today's Order Paper.

I got an application for a building grant for new school accommodation at Knocknaheeny, Cork, on 11 August 1977. Early in 1977, before I took office, my inspector had been in the area appraising the growing suburb and coming to conclusions about what schools would be needed in the future, in so far as that could be done in a developing situation. Approval in principle was given on 25 October 1977 for the provision of two 16-classroom schools. The accommodation will be provided initially in one 16-classroom building, and the additional accommodation will be provided later as the area develops. Both schools will be located on the same site in the townland of Hollyhill.

MainHeading.P: The nub of the question as outlined by Deputy Horgan is about internal organisation, as to whether they should be organised on a single sex or on a co-educational basis. That is, as I stated to-day, a matter not for the Department but for local decision. So far as my Department are concerned if the parents decide that they want a co-educational school in the area, then it will be a co-educational school. Either form of organisation is acceptable to my Department. Deputy Horgan stated that the parents had no way of communicating their views. I find it very hard to accept that from a man who claims he knows their views and that he is expressing their views in this House. There seems to be a lack of logic somewhere in that.

As Deputy Horgan stated at the outset of his speech, a school is desperately needed in the area. It was that I was seized with rather than with anything else. I took steps to see that planning got under way for a school. I stress again that how the school is organised internally must be resolved locally. Any assistance my Department can give to the local interests in their efforts to resolve any differences that may have arisen will be readily forthcoming. I think Deputy Horgan implied that it would not be forthcoming; I say it will be. It is desirable that this matter be settled quickly as planning of the first of the new schools, the 16-classroom school that I mentioned, is going ahead. The accommodation will be required in the near future and it is important that there should be no avoidable delay in providing it.

In any event there will be only one school building initially and it will be necessary to accommodate both boys and girls in that building. Deputy Horgan referred to that. All that seems to be at issue is whether the school should be organised in such a way that there will be separate classes for boys and girls or mixed classes of both boys and girls. Getting a modicum of goodwill it should be possible to resolve that issue locally, speedily. Personally, I would prefer co-educational organisation. What is required is that the local people come together and make their wishes known in a clear, unequivocal way. A group wrote to me about objections to planning applications. I thought it a rather naïve letter because everybody knows that the Minister for Education has no function in regard to planning and the internal organisation of the school has nothing to do with the planning authority under the auspices of the Minister for the Environment. Internal organisation is a matter to be decided at local level and I hope it will be so decided.

In regard to Deputy Horgan's statement that I did not give any information about the financing of the school, I did in fact state that the two schools would cost £760,000, a substantial investment in the area. I am sure that it will provide primary education of a very high standard. Without being accused of being chauvinistic, I think we can say that, both from the point of view of qualifications of teachers and the physical standards of our schools, we have something to be proud of.

Deputy Horgan said that 90 per cent of the people wanted a say in the running of the schools. I think the efforts made over the past few years—I do not claim any credit for them because they had got under way before my time—to involve parents in the management of schools are creditable and have made progress, which I hope will go still further. There has been a deepening of interest of parents in regard to the running of schools. I trust that interest spreads and deepens because in some cases it is not easy to interest people in the actual schools.

Finally, I want to say what I have already repeated twice or three times that in the Department of Education we have not any particular line to follow on whether schools should be co-educational or cater for boys and girls separately. The resources of the Department are available where difficulty has arisen and we are prepared to make those resources available to the people in that area so that they can get the best possible primary education for their children.

Speaker.P: Will the Minister receive a deputation from the community association on this matter?
I could receive a deputation from the parents' representatives in the area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Agriculture (An Comhairle Oiliúna Talmhaíochta) Bill, 1978: Committee Stage.
MainHeading.P: SECTION 1.

Speaker.P: Amendments Nos. 1, 2, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 37, 57, 58 and 70 are consequential on amendment No. 6 and will be discussed together and we can have different decisions on them if necessary.
I move amendment No. 1:
In page 3, subsection (1), lines 20 and 21, to delete “An Chomhairle Oiliúna Talmhaíochta” and substitute “An tÚdarás um Oideachas agus Seirbhís Talmhaíochta”.

This amendment seeks to substitute “education” for “training”. There is no doubt they mean two different things. The title of the previous Act has been changed to read “training” instead of “education”. This is a retrograde step. I do not think the advisory service was ever meant to be a training organisation and it does not act as a training organisation. “Training” means showing someone how to carry out work. In the agricultural advisory service a great deal more is necessary.

The first and primary objective of the advisory service is to educate farmers and to advise them. It is degrading for the agricultural advisory service to say they are training farmers and that they are setting up in the industrial field an organisation similar to AnCO. This appears to be the Minister's intention. I do not believe the advisory service could, or was meant to, work in that way because it would not be good for agriculture. A farmer might need to train a worker who has no experience in operating milking machinery but to say that the advisory service would be training the farmers would not be accepted by them. The agricultural advisory service are educating.
I ask the Minister to accept these amendments.

I support Deputy Bermingham. One of the Minister's major reasons for postponing a decision on the reorganisation of the advisory service, upsetting the work of his predecessor and causing considerable delay, was to enable him to change the word “education” to “training” throughout the Act which had been enacted by his predecessor. His reasons were spurious and at best semantic and did not justify delaying a decision in relation to the advisory service and educational research.

MainHeading.P: The work of this new body will encompass education to a significant degree. Training is part of education, not vice versa.“Education” is the global term and therefore is the term which should be included in the title rather than the narrower term “training”. I am not saying that part of the work of this authority will not encompass training; it will, but it will also encompass education. That is the point being made by Deputy Bermingham. “Education” is a wider term which includes training as well as other aspects of improving the human mind and potential.

I will give a practical example of this. If a farmer is to run his business properly he must know a good deal about economies, changes in the market place, what is proposed in Brussels in relation to farm prices and the relative changes in one commodity as against another. That is economics and nobody would say that when learning economics one is being trained. Studying economics is part of one's education because it is a broad liberal subject and the learning of it is an educational process. The same goes for other aspects of farming. A farmer will have to have a knowledge of geology, soil science, crop husbandry and so on, all very broad subjects involving in many cases significant concepts of an abstract nature. To develop, plan and implement new ideas on his farm, a farmer has to be educated in science. Again, that will be part of the function of this new authority.

The authority will have responsibility for the agricultural schools run by the Department of Agriculture and by various religious orders and foundations with aid from the Department. Is the Minister seriously suggesting that these agricultural colleges are not educational institutions and that their primary purposes is not education? Of course it is. Why then is he so anxious to remove the word “education” where it appeared in the previous Act? To my mind, this is a backward approach to the whole concept.

Training is concerned with teaching people skills, physical or mental, which are essentially repetitive. Education is concerned not just with that. It is concerned with giving people the mental equipment to deal with problems that were unforeseen by the trainer or the educator. There is no doubt that in agricultural education that is what is being done. Farmers are being given information, advice and education so that they can cope with unforeseen problems. That is education in the broad sense. The Minister in going back on the work of his predecessor and substituting the word “training” for “education” is narrowly defining the concept in the Bill and is not in conformity with the facts.

As the Minister has gone to such trouble to change the title and replace the word “education” by “training”, and as this is going into an Act of the Oireachtas—one assumes that if things go into an Act of the Oireachtas they are of some significance because one does not put in or remove something from an Act unless it means something—I want to ask him one question: What does it mean when he substitutes “training” for “education”? Does it mean that some of the courses which are presently being run by bodies which are now being put under the aegis of AnCOT will be restricted because they are not sufficiently orientated and there is too much education involved in them? Does it mean that there will be any practical change? If there is to be a practical change the Minister must tell us now what practical change there will be. If there will not be a practical change I ask him to justify to the House the waste of its time in considering changes in this Bill of his predecessor merely to change words which have no practical meaning.

Speaker.P: I am naturally in support of this amendment because it gets us back to the terminology used in the 1977 Bill, where it was explained that education included training. It was necessary for this Minister to do the same thing and say that training includes education but he wanted to pretend that he was producing something new when he was not. It does not matter a lot what one calls this because it is what is done that matters in the long run.

MainHeading.P: I challenge the right of the Minister to come in here to proceed with the Committee Stage of a Bill that has been radically altered since the Second Stage was discussed. It is not the same Bill because in the first instance the Government were paying the entire cost of those services and now the farmers are being asked by a Government decision to pay the entire cost. Since the discussion took place on the Second Stage we have a completely new Bill. I submit that the correct procedure would now be to have this Bill withdrawn and re-introduced as a new Bill. If this Committee Stage discussion is allowed to take place and a discussion on the other Stages takes place, I believe the Bill will be found to be unconstitutional.

There are a number of reasons why I believe it will be found unconstitutional, not only because we are now discussing a different Bill but also because it is without precedent to single out one section of Irish society and say to them “You must pay the full cost of this service whether or not you use it and the rest of Irish society will pay no part of the bill”. I challenge the right of the House to go ahead with discussion of this Bill which I believe is being illegally discussed in the House.

Speaker.P: There is nothing before the House at the moment but a number of amendments and we must keep fully to them.
It is wrong to proceed with this discussion.
That is not for the Chair.

I am very disappointed that, since the Minister made so many changes in the Bill he failed to heed our plea to put “education” back into the Bill and not allow it to go ahead with the word “training” in it. This matter was dealt with very fully on the Second Reading. Education is vital in the development and the growth of agriculture, because the growth of the nation depends on the growth of agriculture.

MainHeading.P: The insertion of the word “education” would not inhibit the Minister in any way in changing the Bill of his predecessor. Deputy Bruton gave a few practical instances of how the word “education” is needed in agriculture. I would like to refer to a few more. Farm accounts are a very important matter. How many farmers are equipped to do farm accounts? If the Minister asks his civil servants they will tell him how badly equipped farmers are to keep accounts. If they are to run their farms properly or if they are to have any idea of the direction they are going, they must be able to keep accounts. A special course should be introduced and finance should play an important part in it. I appeal to the Minister, even at this late stage, to change his mind on this issue and to substitute the word “education” for the word “training” in the Bill. He is making a vital mistake by downgrading the need for education in agriculture.

Speaker.P: I would like to add my voice to that of the other speakers on this issue. As Deputy Bruton rightly pointed out, a man has to be well educated to farm successfully. It is not a matter of being trained in tractor maintainence or the maintenance of a dairy herd. Every farmer must be well educated to survive. I cannot see any justification for the change the Minister is making. He has a lot more experience of Europe than I have, but the whole emphasis in agriculture in Europe is on education.

A lot of work is being done here by voluntary bodies. We only contribute a very small amount to the Farm Apprenticeship Board who are training for jobs which are in existence. Those jobs have not to be created but those people are being given very little help. There is a great clamour at the moment for more places in agriculture colleges. How many people were refused places in those colleges this year? What are the Minister's plans for a new college? The whole emphasis must be on education if farming is to survive and to do well under EEC regulations. The Minister's Bill would be improved by inserting the word “education” in the title. The spotlight is on the education of young people.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Bruton spoke about the diversity of farming. We have now new problems because of intensification. The farmer has to know a lot about fungicides and herbicides. The farmer has to be well up in fungicides and herbicides and must literally be a veterinary surgeon in his own right. If he is in the beef or pig industry he has a lot to learn. He must have a broad education to cope with the new situation. He needs a wealth of experience. The whole emphasis of this Bill should be on education. I would ask the Minister to co-operate with us and allow that word to stand.

Speaker.P: I understood the amendments to relate to the Title of the Bill. We have had a repetition of the Second Stage discourse on what Deputy Bruton has called the semantics of the choice between the words “training” and “education”. Deputy Bermingham says that there is a difference and in the interests of accuracy and the proper use of the most accurate words, either in Irish or English, I felt the word “training” or “Comhairle Oiliúna” should be used in the Title of the Bill. Incidentally we use the Irish title since this is Ireland. I felt the new authority should have an Irish title, which it did not have under the old regime because of ancient, inherited inclinations which are traceable to its origins.
The Minister is really scraping the ground.
This is original stuff. It is knockabout farce.

Having called the difference semantic and therefore of no particular importance, Deputy Bruton went on to say that there are specialist subjects such as farm economics and soil science. I did not grasp at that stage whether Deputy Clinton envisages in the future educational establishments where degree courses or third-level courses of some kind would be provided in those and many other specialised skills.

MainHeading.P: What Fianna Fáil have in mind is the production of better farmers by training them better in their jobs. We are assuming that a good general education will already have been received by those who will be the main users of comhairle services. I would think the use of the word “education” is proper, meaning the drawing out of a particular person and his equipment with a fairly wide general knowledge. I do not foresee a time when every farmer will be a very specialised fountain of knowledge about soil science, soil chemistry, physics and geology, crop husbandry and parasitology and so on. That is really going to the level of semantics. We had a declared intention of establishing a training organisation, not similar to but related to the AnCO service for the provision of better technicians. These technicians work on the land with animals and with crops. It is precisely as Deputy Bermingham suggested. There is an important difference, but we did not go for the general and more diffuse objective of a specialised agricultural education which would probably be conferred to some degree by a third-level course in agriculture such as provided by the universities. Such a course is not available to the average farmer. It may be available to Fine Gael farmers but not to farmers as a whole. We must provide a better service than the one which is available already and that is the intention in the Bill. That is the reason for changing the title. We express our intention succinctly by our selection of words in the Title of the Bill.

Speaker.P: If——
I would remind Deputy Bruton that I have not interrupted him or any of his colleagues and I would ask him, for the same courtesy, if he can manage it.
I will.

Advisory work is evolving at a very rapid rate and since our entry to the Community the whole complexion of agriculture has been revolutionised. Sometimes this simple message takes a long time to percolate into various quarters of our society, not necessarily political quarters. We have to contemplate the situation where there will be rapid change. I imagine there will be rapid change in the advisory field within the next decade and there may be a necessity to amend this Bill, for instance. Rapid changes are taking place in the field of specialist advice. The old-fashioned GP agricultural advisers provided by the committees of agriculture have been doing trojan work and will continue to do so, but there is a new process going on. Interestingly, it is being financed in the dairy sector by the dairy co-operatives. Interesting inquiries are being made by meat firms as well regarding animal husbandry and meat production and it is in that area that we must envisage the provision of specialist advisers, not general practitioners. In some cases these specialist advisers work with committees of agriculture and ideally that is how they all ought to work.

In the dairying sector they are working in order to raise farmers' incomes and output and thereby guarantee employment and throughput in their own factories. It is motivated by very mundane factors. In the meat industry it is a general truth to say that we do not have meat processing plants as much as slaughter houses exporting slaughtered meat. There were fewer facilities a few years ago than there are now for the enterprising beef processer who wished to process his meat further. The inhibitions that the meat processer laboured under a couple of years ago have been removed. In that context there is need for training. It is not education and that is why I am asking the House to reject these amendments.

I am not very impressed by what the Minister has said: that he chose the right word in “training” as opposed to “education”. As he said, the agriculture industry will be expanding and will be revolutionised. It will be revolutionised by new methods and the farmer, who will be a free agent, will have to be educated. The Minister is juggling with words when he says that it is training, because to me it is educating the farmer to do the right thing. The farmer must be convinced first of all, and that means that he must be educated.

MainHeading.P: The Minister said that the ordinary farmer will probably never be a scientist for testing soil and I agree with that. These tests must be carried out as an educational process and the farmer must be shown what he can grow in that soil and the methods that should be used. That is education, not training. A man cannot be trained how to operate a tractor. He must be educated on how to run his farm properly and how to use his soil to the best advantage. “Education” is the paramount word in this issue.

Speaker.P: I am more than disappointed with the Minister's answer to the case we have made. The Minister is now stating clearly that there is now no need for agricultural education.
I never said that.
I am offering an alternative to what the Minister said.
Over what period does the Deputy envisage his type of education being conveyed? Could it be conveyed by means of a few night classes?

No, it could not. It is a permanent process, whether it is done through night classes or county committees of agriculture. The knowledge is in the Agricultural Institute. They have the technical knowledge and it is up to them to convey it to the farmer through the agricultural adviser. The Minister is splitting this. About 60 per cent of the farmers have not got this knowledge. In this Bill the Minister is locking up this knowledge and putting it into safes in the Agricultural Institute. I am more than disappointed at the Minister's whole approach. I interpret what he said to mean that there is not a great need for agricultural education.
I did not say that. The Deputy should not put words into my mouth.

With the Minister as head of agriculture this is a fatal situation. The Minister is making a big error here and may direct those who are involved in agricultural training and research in the wrong direction.

MainHeading.P: The Minister mentioned the AnCO courses. These are three month courses. The Minister asked me if this could be done in six weeks. It cannot be done in six weeks. It must be an ongoing process related to the type of farming the person is carrying out. That is what agricultural education has to be. The AnCO courses train a man to cut out a piece of iron and measure it. It is not the same in farming. There is the question of finance, which is massive in agriculture. If a farmer does not have proper knowledge of how to borrow money and invest it, great mistakes can be made. The Minister knows this as well as I do. Farmers must be educated on how to invest money whether it be in machinery, land or stock. No comparison can be drawn between the need for education in agriculture and the AnCO courses and this is what the Minister has done. He is on the wrong track.
As regards specialist fields, the creameries are specialists in milk production. Are they specialists in all other sides of farming?

Speaker.P: Yes. There is no reason why——
These people will be specialised and trained in milk production and milk production only.
Does the Minister disapprove of that?

No, it is a very good development but it will not take care of the entire need in the milk industry as far as the farmer is concerned. It is vital that he is trained in the use of finance, AI and equipment. These are all separate things from what the Minister is talking about. There is also the question of producing feed for cows. A man in milk production is not qualified in some of these fields—for example, in cereals.
The Deputy will find that most of them are very good.

I disagree with the Minister. He is on the wrong track. The question of any firm having a specialist trained man is not sufficient for today's farming. I am more than disappointed that the Minister is saying that there is no real need for agricultural education. Anything we say will not change the Minister's mind.

I thought the Minister was coming around to our way of thinking when he said that the adviser of the future would have to be more of a specialist. I agree with that. We are in a very specialist area. If that is brought a little further it will be realised that farm education is an ongoing process. With all the third level education in the world the farmer still has to keep up with changing times.
That is correct.
The advantage of a broad education in agriculture is that he would know how to avail of all the facts and figures. A farmer, just like a doctor, has to keep up with the times.
The Deputy should not compare our trade with that of a doctor.
Farming is changing from day to day——
I agree.
——and “education” is the operative word.

May I take it from what the Minister has said that the change he is making in relation to this matter as regards the Bill introduced by his predecessor is purely a change in words and that it makes no practical difference?
There is a change in philosophy behind the change of words.
What concrete changes will there be in the work of agricultural colleges such as Warrenstown?

We are back to the Fine Gael dilemma about education and their evident incapacity to grasp this simple point. A young man or woman going into farming is almost always well educated. This applies to young people going into engineering or whatever. Thereafter he goes to work. Sometimes he has a year in an agricultural school and sometimes he has a farm apprenticeship that is concerned with the training of the going out and doing farming work. None of that is education. It is training the young person to do his job better that he would have done otherwise. It is essential.

Deputy Bermingham, in his philosophical approach to this, said that I was degrading agriculture, as if to suggest we were merely training them—not educating them—but expecting them to be already educated to some degree. Education must be a general approach. It is the evolution of a philosophy suitable to the job you are doing. Training consists of the mechanics of doing the job. You are taking a young person by the hand and saying “This is the way to do it. You watch me doing it”. That is training and that is largely what the new organisation will be doing. They will be dealing with people who are actually farming for their living. The main task is to improve their living and by any stretch of the imagination and with a middling understanding of the King's English to call that “education” is a too liberal extension of the word. It is training and there is nothing debasing about it. It is ennobling rather than debasing. If Fine Gael Deputies could grasp this simple point there would be no need for what they themselves have called all these semantics.

I agree with much of what the Minister has said. Training a young man is showing him the way to do the job. Farmers will have a basic education, possibly even a good education, which will probably include even a farm apprenticeship. Farming is a complex subject and there will have to be several new approaches with regard to our processing industries. Education is necessary to show what are the right kinds of operations. That is the predominant part of the advisory services programme. To me education is showing a person what is the right and economical thing to do. The farmer is quite capable of doing the job but often he is not convinced that it is the right thing to do. This is where education comes in.

I asked the Minister a very simple question. I asked if there was any practical significance in the change he made in substituting the word “training” for “education” or if it was purely a change of words. The Minister said there was a change in philosophy. I asked if he could give me a concrete example of how this changed philosophy would be expressed, for instance, in the courses that might be given at Warrenstown college or in the work of the advisory services. If there is a change in philosophy presumably it means something and, therefore, influences the activities being run under this institution. I should like the Minister to give me not a lecture but concrete examples. What changes will occur in the operation of the advisory services under this Bill because the word “training” has been substituted for the word “education” that would not have happened under the old Bill? What changes will occur in the operation of agricultural colleges under this Bill now that they are described as being engaged in training that would not have happened if the old Bill with the word “education” was left? If there is a change in philosophy there must be a change in practice because philosophy that does not affect practice is not worth talking about. I should like the Minister to tell us exactly the type of changes he has in mind resulting from this momentous change in the use of words that he has inserted in this Bill.

I had thought that the debate on Second Stage would have introduced some glimmer of light into this matter. It appears that Opposition Deputies have difficulty in comprehending the basics of this matter. Deputy Bruton wants concrete examples. There are dozens of things one could say.

MainHeading.P: One of the great sources of mastitis infection in dairy herds at present is the improper use of milking machine apparatus. There are certain techniques that can be learned and instructions can be given about them in centres of education in a short period. These instructions can be given in agricultural colleges—I presume they are—and in classes conducted by committees of agriculture—as I presume they are. A great deal of information about this and other matters is disseminated by An Foras Talúntais. The farmer can be equipped with new knowledge in a short period but by no stretch of the imagination could the conveying of that specialised knowledge be called education.
Deputy D'Arcy put words into my mouth to the effect that I said education was not important. It is all-important.

Speaker.P: Why downgrade it?

The proper assimilation of facts like this is related to a more general education in the basics that every child normally gets at secondary school. I am talking about physics and chemistry. That will teach a child the rudiments of soil chemistry. Physics deal with the behaviour of soil under different moisture conditions and many other things. Of course mathematics also come into it. It is the rudimentary gateway to the whole area of farming financing and surveying. Without this general education the farmer will always be at a disadvantage and he will have to make up himself where he is deficient. Many of them, particularly the successful farmers, can do this.

I am talking about a more specialised type of training that will help farmers to face the next decade to begin with. In the next decade we will be looking for rapid increases in production in the dairy, meat, pigs, cereal and sugar beet sectors. We have the potential to get them. We have the knowledge that our present performance is nothing like it should be. The most acute requirement is specialist training.

Many Fine Gael Deputies—not the Deputies who have contributed to this debate—find out about farming matters second-hand. They would need to recognise the state of rapid change our agricultural economy is in and its enormous potential, that there is a pressing need for better training of the young men and women going into the industry. They will need a lot of education with a little bit of farming flair. That is the error Fine Gael are falling into. We are not dealing with general airy-fairy things here. We are dealing with opportunities and special requirements.

I asked the Minister for a concrete example of the change that will occur in the practice of the advisory and educational services as a result of the Minister's substitution of the word “training” for “education” throughout the Bill. He gave me an example. He spoke of the improper use of milking machines causing mastitis and he said that short courses could be run to teach farmers how properly to use milking machines. He gave that as an example of a change that would occur as a result of changing the word “education” to “training”. I want to be clear if the Minister is saying that a course like that could not have been run by the National Agricultural Authority set up by his predecessor and which will now be run by the new authority. Is that what the Minister has been saying?
I am saying that “training” is a better word. The other word reflects the error and the falseness of the Fine Gael philosophy. Coming from the richer farmers, Fine Gael have no time——
These are such pearls of wisdom——
We would get on much better one at a time. We cannot have question and answer across the House. Deputies can pose questions and let the Minister reply to them.
The Minister interrupted me and I crave your protection against any further political incursions——
I do not think you need much protection, so far at any rate.

I do not think the Minister seriously meant that a course could not have been run under the NAA but that it can now be run under the new authority because of the use of the word “training”. If the Minister did not mean that, what he said is not an answer to my question. I know the Minister loves to answer general questions which enables him to go on a long verbal voyage on which few of us can follow him, so I will ask him a simple question. What change in the curricula of the agricultural colleges, say in Warrenstown, will take place because they will be under a training authority instead of an educational authority? Does he think that changes will be made as a result of this, that there will be a change in philosophy, not merely a change in words? Does he believe that these colleges, which previously were operating under an educational Act, will now change their courses in any material or philosophical way? If they are not to change their courses, then this is merely a change of words and of no significance. If they are to change their courses, then there is to be a change in philosophy. If the latter is so the Minister should tell us precisely what the change will be.

Deputy Bruton is asking me in effect to look into my crystal ball and say what the comhairle will do about courses in any year. It is not in my capacity to do that. What is in my capacity to do, and I will do it in due course, is to compose the board in a certain way. I have adverted to the importance of the food processing industry to the whole farming sector and its growth. I am glad of this because it is producing more jobs on the land than off it. People in that industry will have a new strong voice in the formulation of the comhairle and it is they, not I, who will determine the policy of the comhairle. Naturally, I will consult with the comhairle from time to time on the general scheme of work and any Minister for Agriculture will consult with the comhairle on certain aspects that he considers to be of special importance. That is only right because we must remember that we are here in an Irish Parliament, the meeting place of the democratically elected representatives of the people. If this Parliament ceases to be that, we are all in trouble.
Therefore, the answer to Deputy Bruton's question is that I cannot say in advance what the council will do, but I have certain ideas on how they should be composed.

The composition of the comhairle has been laid down in the Bill and the Minister has only a small say in regard to the people who will compose it because most of them will be nominated by different bodies. Therefore, answering my question by reference to the composition of the board is not an answer at all. The number of people the Minister will be appointing will be quite small and therefore I do not see how he could make any significant difference in the overall result. He has said that by the substitution of one word for another he is asking the House to agree to a major change in philosophy, yet when he was asked to give concrete examples of the possible results of that change he said that would be a matter for the board. He is not coming clean with the House. The Minister went to the trouble of making this change, and regardless of the board he must have a clear idea of what this major change will be in terms of practical results in County Kilkenny and elsewhere. All the Minister has said is that it is a matter for the board, and I do not think the House should be asked to agree to buy a pig in a poke, which, on the face of it, is a regressive move.

I am glad the Minister at least said that the question of education is all important. He stressed the need for general education and specialised advice through short courses. I do not accept that. Education in farming must be a continuing process. There must be courses over a three-year period, the majority of which would have to be night courses. The Minister gave an instance of mastitis and said the greatest reason for it is the wrong use of machines. That is not correct. There are various reasons for the high incidence of mastitis and if the Minister believes he will train a milk man by some short course on how to put the cups on the teats, that that is all that is needed, he is on the wrong track as far as milk production is concerned.
That is only a clever answer.

These fundamental problems are the Minister's problems. He is in charge of agriculture and it is our duty to point them out to him. Why is the overall milk production down to 640 gallons per cow while across the water it is 1,000 gallons per cow? Why are we producing only two tons of barley per acre while across the water they are producing three tons of barley per acre? The Minister must answer these questions and satisfy us. He must also try to satisfy the farmers. It is his job to educate the farmers. Lack of education is the cause of the problems. The Minister has never had such a good opportunity to put these courses into operation, but his actions are only isolating the Agricultural Institute.
It is time the Chair put the amendment.

This body will be looked upon only as an agricultural training authority with no advisory function. That is the principal reason the board must be seen to have a broader base. Even the Minister admits that it has an educational function. The agricultural adviser must also be a development officer. The production of water schemes and so on for farmers is a broader issue than training. The Minister is taking a retrograde step in eliminating education. The idea is abroad that the authority will only be a training authority, and I appeal to the Minister to include education.
Amendment put and declared lost.

Section 1 (2) reads:

This Act shall come into operation on such day or days as may be fixed therefore by order or orders of the Minister either generally or by reference to any particular purpose or provision and different days may be so fixed for different purposes and different provisions.

Since the Bill was discussed on Second Stage the context of it has been changed by the announcement in the budget of a levy on agricultural products. I introduced an amendment which has been ruled out of order.

I want to ensure that the Bill is not paid for by a levy. I was told by the Chair that this must be adjudged out of order because it is not relevant to the provisions of the Bill as read a Second Time.

Question proposed: “That section 3 stand part of the Bill.”

This is the most important section in this Bill. We will contest it very strongly here because of something that has happened in relation to the expenses of the comhairle since this Bill passed Second Stage. It is stated in the Bill that the expenses incurred by the Minister in the administration of this Act shall “to such extent as may be sanctioned by the Minister for Finance” be paid out of money provided by the Oireachtas. However, since this Bill passed Second Stage it has been made known by the Minister for Finance that the expenses of this Bill will be paid for by a levy on farmers.

I have already told Deputy Bruton that we are not discussing the levy on this Bill. Deputy Bruton put in an amendment which was ruled out of order by the Ceann Comhairle. He cannot come in and discuss that amendment on this Bill. There is no way in which the Chair will allow that.
It has been clearly stated——
I told Deputy Bruton on the previous section that we will not discuss the levy on this Bill. The Deputy can discuss it tomorrow.

On a point of order, how the Bill will be financed is specifically stated in section 3. I maintain that there has been a change in the method of financing since the Bill was introduced and therefore I hold that it is relevant to discuss this matter on this section.

The Chair has already ruled. Deputies can discuss the expenses of the comhairle any way they like, but the Chair has already ruled that we will not discuss the levy on this Bill and the amendment to that effect has already been ruled out of order by the Ceann Comhairle.
Is it not a fact that this levy is now financing this Bill?
As far as the Chair is concerned it is not a fact. The Chair has already ruled that we will not discuss the levy on this Bill. I would ask Deputies to accept that ruling.

I would like to know exactly how the expenses of the comhairle will be met. Will the Minister give us the details of how the expenses of the comhairle will be funded? Can the Minister give an assurance that the moneys voted for the comhairle will be voted from the general fund of the Exchequer, that the expenses of the comhairle will bear no relation whatever to any specific tax but will come out of the general fund?

We want to hear what the Minister for Agriculture thinks about matters that affect——

Speaker.P: Amendment No. 3. Amendments Nos. 17, 29, 31, 38, 41, 42, 45, 46, 49 and 52 are consequential on amendment No. 3. Amendments Nos. 16, 28, 30, 39, 40, 43, 47, 50, 53 and 69 are related. We will have amendment No. 3 moved and discuss amendments Nos. 16, 17, 28, 31, 38, 39, 40, 41——
This is the first notice we have got of the linking of those amendments. Could the Chair give us the numbers again?
