I move amendment No. 3:
In page 3, line 44, to delete “‘education’”.

The issue is not very different from the one we discussed earlier in relation to amendments Nos. 1 and 2. They concern the change which is being made by the Minister in the use of the word “education” and its substitution by “training”. We have gone almost as far as one could productively go in discussing this issue because the Minister, despite repeated invitations, has not given any significant indication as to what difference in practice will result, in different colleges or in the advisory services of different counties, because those bodies according to this Bill are no longer to be concerned with education but with training.

MainHeading.P: The Minister has not given us examples. However, he has told us that because the change is being made, that the word “education” is being replaced throughout the Bill with the word “training”, this involves a major change in philosophy. Those are the Minister's words. We have been trying to get an answer from him as to what in practice this major change in philosophy means. The best example of all to cite, because it will most likely be affected by the change in philosophy, is the work of the agricultural colleges. Those have been known by many people throughout the country as educational institutions. Places like Warrenstown College are undoubtedly educational institutions. They involve the education of young farmers. They are concerned with practical agriculture but they are also concerned with wider educational issues, helping them to be good, efficient farmers.

The Minister has made a deliberate decision to change the Bill under which those educational institutions will operate by substituting throughout the Bill the word “training” for the word “education” in relation to their role. I would like to know what in practice will be the changes that will occur in those colleges as a result of this. The Minister has said that this is primarily a matter for the new board of agriculture but that new board does not yet exist. The Minister is making changes in the Act now and in so doing he must have some idea as to what results will be brought about by these changes which, he says, represent a major change in philosophy. He must have some idea how the changes will affect courses in the agricultural colleges.

I hope the Minister will come clean this time and say precisely what he has in mind. In the case of agricultural colleges, does he want any of the courses operating at present to be dropped because they are too educational and have not a sufficient training bias? Will he write to the colleges drawing their attention to the provisions of the Act and telling them they have no business carrying on a particular course because it constitutes education and not training? We know that what is mentioned “in the Act” is of great importance. People in the public service will sometimes say they cannot do a certain thing because it is not authorised in the Act.

As the Minister has gone to such trouble to change “education” to “training” throughout the Bill, are there some activities of the advisory service or of the agricultural colleges to which he objects because they are too educational and not sufficiently of a training nature? If so, he should say so; if not, he should tell us why it is necessary to make the changes at all. What is the point of this change if there is not to be a change on the ground? If there is to be a change, what is it? Does the Minister anticipate that any change will be made in the activities of the agricultural colleges? Does he anticipate that any direction will be issued by his Department to the agricultural colleges because of the major change in philosophy in this Bill and on foot of the substitution of the word “training” for “education”? I should like a frank answer because it is impossible to carry on any debate on the merits or demerits of the substitution of the word “training” if we do not know what the practical results will be and if the Minister will not give explicit answers to these questions.

Speaker.P: We must repeat much that we have said during the discussion of this Bill. We have taken into account the substitution of the word “training” for the word “education”. I was glad to hear the Minister say that education is all important. The emphasis throughout the Bill should be on education.

The county committees of agriculture went to great expense over the years in building offices in most districts within their administrative areas and the purpose of these offices was the on-going education of farmers. It will be a backward step if the Minister believes training is all that is needed in agriculture today. The offices to which I have referred operated the EEC schemes. Much of this educational work must be carried on after working hours, that is, after 6 p.m. As a member of the Wexford County Committee of Agriculture, I believe that farmers need on-going educational courses. MainHeading.P: I have emphasised low production rates right across the board. Certain farmers have reached a very high level of production, but they have educated and trained themselves in their own specialist fields. They represent only 5 per cent or 10 per cent of those engaged in agriculture. I am prepared to back that up with figures. While I was chairman of the Wexford County Committee of Agriculture I asked the chief agricultural officer for some indication of how we stood in relation to maximum production. All the evidence is available in the Minister's office. Our average milk production is about 650 gallons per cow. We produce on average two tons of barley per acre and approximately the same amount of wheat. Certainly we have advanced over the years in the production of beet and I believe this was done by education.

I am prepared to speak on this Bill as often as possible in an effort to persuade the Minister of the absolute need for education in agriculture. There is much leeway to be made up and the Minister must realise this.

Short crash courses of six or seven weeks' duration, such as those organised by AnCO, are completely inadequate. The proper course takes approximately three years, based on 100 hours per year. People with specialised knowledge must be brought in to educate people.

The Minister failed to answer my question. He decided he could get out of the question by saying I asked about Warrenstown. I asked about agricultural colleges in general. The Minister has direct responsibility for Ballyhaise.
We are in the process of continuing change. How often must I say this?
I would like to know if we are in the process of continuing change.
I will say it again if the Deputy would like me to.

We are in a process of continuing change because the world is changing, but the Minister is seeking to move that change in a particular direction so far as agricultural education is concerned by the change of “education” to “training”. I do not want to lecture about general agricultural trends——

I would hope that as a result of the Bill in general and the new approach to the question of agricultural advice and training there will be many dramatic changes. It is safe to say that in relation to the level of dairy and cereal production, both of which Deputy D'Arcy mentioned, and in the matter of farm incomes and the propagation of knowledge the facilities available will be expanded.

One of the main purposes of the Bill is to establish a council or comhairle of agricultural instruction. That is what the title signifies. The task of procuring these ends will be given to them. They and I, or my successor, will take counsel together from time to time in the light of the existing circumstances and so adapt their training to that best suited to the requirements of the young people going into farming.

MainHeading.P: The contributions made by the Fine Gael Deputies so far have been a reversion to the old situation and the underlining implication that farmers, by definition, are a rather ignorant lot who require education. Does anybody contemplate a parallel establishment for the legal or medical profession or that they should have re-education courses? Is it not always assumed that they are educated already? Sometimes it is inaccurate to make that assumption but it is made automatically. It is not made in the case of farmers. That philosophic flaw is absolutely endemic in Fine Gael; they cannot get rid of it because they come from the better endowed section of the agricultural population, or at least many of them come from that section. They may have had the advantages of a better quality education than many of the young people going into farming who cannot aspire to it. However, they can aspire to something much more than they could aspire to ten or 15 years ago. The reason is that the Fianna Fáil Government of the time provided the facilities for a good secondary education and it is on this question that Fine Gael are having all the trouble.

We must begin with the person who is well educated, the young man or the girl leaving a second-level school with a leaving certificate. Upon that minimum we build and if further education is required it will have to be third level. The inbetween, the applied training, is being provided by AnCOT and the advisory services. In my opinion the function of the advisory services will gravitate towards the planned production of crops and animals, towards a particular objective. The simplest case to understand is that which is taking place by itself on the farmers' own initiative, assisted in some cases by the county committee of agriculture, in the matter of boosting dairy production. This is not merely a matter of animal nutrition. It cannot avoid involving pasture management, a considerable amount of animal husbandry and animal genetics. It embraces the raising of the average lactation levels and many specialised matters such as animal nutrition and so on. There is the question of production of crops as ration supplements and the production of cereals. What puts the butter on the bread or dairy farmers is the level of dairy production——

Speaker.P: What has this to do with the question I asked about agricultural colleges?
The more efficient the comhairle can make a man at his job the better. They will be judged by the criteria of performance and results.

I am asking him if he is making the change from education to training safe in the knowledge that the results of this change are so impossible to predict that he cannot give a single example of what might happen in Ballyhaise Agricultural College.

I have conveyed that the comhairle will deal with it competently. I can assure the House that they will not again experience the real values of Fine Gael with the completion of the NAAERA board that is now dead. On 5 July 1977, the last day they held office——
The Minister should answer the question.
That was the answer. Those Deputies answered it themselves.
This is getting more uninteresting as we go on. The Minister has claimed——
I will not take lectures from Fine Gael on these matters.
As a Member of this House I am entitled to discuss this Bill. I am not lecturing the Minister but he lectured us about Fine Gael and what they stand for.

Question proposed: “That section 4 stand part of the Bill.”
Are we taking a vote on the other amendments.
We will take them as we go along.
We have only dealt with No. 3.
Amendment No. 4 is out of order because it proposes to impose a charge on the Revenue. Amendment No. 5 is also out of order. There are no further relevant amendments to the section.

Section 4 is an objectionable one. One of its purposes is to exclude the word “education” and to substitute the word “training”. Other parts of the section are also objectionable, particularly the deletion of section 22 of the 1977 Act and the deletion of section 48 (3) and (4) of that Act. We object to the removal of these two provisions. First, I would like to deal with the removal of section 22. The best way to deal with this matter is to read the section in the 1976 Act. Section 22 reads:

(1) Subject to subsection (2), the Authority may charge, receive and recover fees for agricultural research or basic veterinary research undertaken on behalf of any person, firm, institution or agency and for services, courses, seminars, lectures and demonstrations provided or organised by it.

MainHeading.P: (2) No fee may, however, be charged in respect of—
(a) any advice that may be given by the Authority in response to a request from the Minister under section 21, or
(b) any facilities, assistance or courses of instruction that may be provided by the Authority under Section 14 or Section 16 (b),

but the cost to the Authority of providing the services referred to in this subsection shall rank as an expense on the Authority and shall be taken into account when the amount of the annual grant referred to in section 48 (1) (b) is being determined.

I would like to concentrate on the words, “No fee may be charged in respect of any facilities, assistance or courses of instruction that may be provided by the authority under section 14 or section 16 (b)”. Section 14 concerns courses in agriculture for the purpose of implementing the EEC directives and section 16 (b) relates to the authorities who provide such facilities and assistance. Section 21 says:
The Authority shall advise the Minister on any matter relating to agricultural education, advice or research or to basic veterinary research on which its views are requested by the Minister.
What is the significance of deleting section 22?

Speaker.P: It is consequential on the separation of An Foras Talúntais, the body responsible for veterinary research and all other types of agricultural research. These are being put in the place where they properly belong, in An Foras Talúntais. That is the only reason this change is being made.

Section 14 of the original Act states that the authority shall provide courses in agriculture for the purpose of implementing directives of the EEC when requested to do so by the Minister. I presume that section 14 of the original Act would relate to courses under Directive 161. Under the original Act as introduced by the former Minister, Deputy Clinton, it was clearly stated in section 22 (2) that no fee could be charged for these courses. Now the Minister is removing the provision that no fee can be charged for these courses.
Section 14 of the old Act is not referred to by section 4.
Section 14 of the old Act is referred to by section 22 of the old Act. One of the purposes of section 4 of this Bill is to delete or repeal section 22 of the old Act.
That is the way the research functions.
I am using the 1976 Act. Is the whole of section 22 to be deleted?

Section 22 (1) of the 1976 Act relates to the charging of fees for agricultural research, basic veterinary research and so on undertaken on behalf of any person, firm, institution, agency and so forth.

I will go along with that. The Minister is removing that because this institution will be carrying out research and therefore that does not arise. I see the relevance of that but I cannot see the relevance of the removal of section 22 (2).
Again there is nothing sinister. The research element has gone but nothing else has gone.
Yes, but the Minister is removing the entire section 22.
No.
Yes. Section 4 of the present Bill says:
The following provisions of the Act of 1977 are hereby repealed:

MainHeading.P: The Minister is removing the entire section 22. I can understand why he is removing section 22 (1).

Speaker.P: Section 22 of the old Act says that no fee, however, may be charged in respect of any advice given by the authority in response to a request by the Minister under section 21.
That is part (a). What about (b)?
What does the Deputy object to there?
I want to find out what it is first before I object to it in section 22 (2) (b).
The total deletion of section 22 of the old Act will mean that there will now be no provision whatever for the charging of fees in that area.
Would the Minister mind repeating that?
The deletion of the whole of section 22 means that there is now no provision for the charging of fees for these functions.

I see, but I do not believe that section 22 (2) relates in any way to the matters covered by section 22 (1). Section 22 (1) is concerned with agricultural research or basic veterinary research undertaken on behalf of any person, firm or agency and it says a fee may be charged for that. Section 22 (2) (b) relates to facilities, assistance or courses of instruction and these are further amplified as being courses of instruction under section 14 or section 16 (b) which are EEC courses. Section 22 (2) contained a clear guarantee that no fees would be charged for these courses of instruction. Section 22 (2), which deals with courses, must be read separately from section 22 (1), which deals with research. In removing section 22 (2) the Minister is removing a guarantee which existed against the charge of fees for courses of instruction.
We are making no reference of any kind to the charging of fees.
The Minister is removing part of a section which said that:
No fee may, however, be charged in respect of—(b) any facilities, assistance or courses of instruction that may be provided by the Authority under section 14.

Taking it all together the section provides for the charging of certain fees in certain cases and goes on to say that they will not be charged in certain other cases. The deletion of the whole section means that there is no reference good or bad to the collection of fees.
Do the Minister, AnCOT or the county committees of agriculture have power at the moment to charge a fee for courses or advice?
The deletion of section 22 removes the power given to the Minister under the old Act to charge fees for veterinary or other research.

That is in so far as basic agriculture or veterinary research is concerned. Do the county committees of agriculture at the moment if they wish have the power to charge a fee for courses they might give under Directive 161, for example?
Not as far as I know.
It is very important that the Minister be more precise in that.
I would like to go into this in greater depth. It is a bit inconvenient to deal with it now. We could come back to this on Report Stage and get some clarity into the definition.
There is no lack of clarity on my part.
The section itself does not leave the situation clear enough. It might need to be clarified further by a Report Stage amendment.
What I am worried about is that section 22 (2) contains a guarantee that no fees may be charged for EEC courses. Section 22 is being removed in toto, including that guarantee.
Including guarantees to charge them.
But also the guarantee that they will not be charged in respect of courses.
There is a bit of good news and a bit of bad in the section.

If section 22 (1) and 22 (2) are interdependent there is no problem, but if they are independent there is a problem because the guarantee in section 22 (2) is being removed. It is particularly important to know if the fact that the guarantee is being removed means anything. If in removing that guarantee we are leaving a situation where committees of agriculture or AnCOT can legally charge fees under the 1931 Act or some other Act for some of their activities we are making a significant change which should not be made. Before we agree to the removal of section 22 (2) it is important to know if its being removed will enable county committees of agriculture to be free under the 1931 Act, or legislation going further back, to charge fees.

Even with the legal knowledge which the Deputy is using to advantage here, he may be wrong. In relation to section 22, subject to subsection (2), the authority may charge. Subsection (2) says “no fee may, however, be charged”. Outside these narrow definitions permission to charge fees is granted by section 22 of the old Act, as I understand it.
Would the Minister not be better off, if that is what he intends, instead just to remove section 22 (1) and leave section 22 (2)?
No.
Why? As the Minister pointed out, section 22 (1) is subservient to section 22 (2). The Minister would achieve what he wants if he just removed section 22 (1) and left section 22 (2) there.
I am advised that there may have to be an amendment to achieve that.
Can I have the Minister's assurance that it is his intention that the authority will not have the statutory authority to charge fees for the courses referred to.
I undertake to ensure that this is greatly clarified. I concede, that this leaves a certain amount of doubt. I will have it clarified on Report Stage.

I am asking a question of political policy. It can be clarified in any number of ways. For instance, it could be clarified in a way that would give the authority complete freedom to charge fees for anything, or it could be clarified in the way that I would like: that they would not be able to charge fees at all. The Minister just saying that it will be clarified by an unspecified amendment does not really meet the case I am making. In principle, does the guarantee contained in section 22 (2) that no fee may be charged in respect of facilities, assistance or courses of instruction that may be provided under EEC schemes——
I will not give the Deputy that guarantee without further examining this section.
The Minister must know whether or not he intends to give AnCOT the power to charge fees for courses. That is a question of policy, not a question of obtuse argument.
No. It is not related to what one intends; it could conceivably relate to unnecessary inhibitions to progress in the future. It is quite impossible to say.
The Minister does not really know whether he intends to allow the comhairle to have the power to charge fees for EEC courses. He does not know whether he wants them to have that power or not.
The area of uncertainty embraces the changes that may take place that we do not now anticipate, that we could not possibly anticipate.
Does the Minister think that in this category of change there are changes which might justify the charging of fees for the EEC courses and is that why he does not want to give a guarantee?
I submit that the exclusion of the possibility would be very ill-advised. The restriction of your own freedom would be ill-advised.

We are getting a little nearer to what the Minister really thinks. He thinks it would be ill-advised for a guarantee to be given that fees would not be charged for courses of instruction under the authority. It is quite clear that his predecessor did not feel the same——
On the contrary, it is quite clear that he did intend to charge fees.
He did not. He specified in his Bill that fees would not be charged.
In a certain very limited area. In all the rest he specifically provided for the charging of fees in those sectors in section 22 (1).
That is only in relation to research and it is to be read subject to section 22 (2).
It also related to courses, seminars and things like that, lectures and demonstrations provided or organised by it. All these in section 1, positively involved the charging of fees in the 1976 Act.

They are not positively included. All that is positively included is in section 22 (1) which says that the authority may charge fees for agricultural research or basic veterinary research undertaken on behalf of any person, firm, institution, or agency——

What the Deputy has slurred over is the important bit—“and for services, courses, seminars, lectures and demonstrations provided or organised by it”. Do not monkey with your volume when you are saying it.

It goes on to say that no fee may be charged in respect of advice given by the authority to the Minister under section 21 or any facilities, assistance or courses of instruction provided by the authority under sections 14 or 16 (b). The Minister is removing the guarantee on these in section 22 (2). He is also removing section 22 (1). I would like to know would it have been necessary to have section 22 (1) for fees to be charged for courses, seminars, lectures, demonstrations and so on? Was the position prior to the enactment of that Act that no fees could be charged legally and that it was necessary to have section 22 (1) to allow such fees to be charged? If that were the case it is not such a problem but if the case were that section 22 (1) did not really make any difference, that they had power to charge these fees in any case, then the important part is section 22 (2). Therefore my question is an important one: what was the position about the charging of fees before any of these pieces of legislation were introduced?

The best thing to do here is to go over section 22 and examine what the Minister at the time had in mind. It says that subject to subsection 2—which we will come to later—the authority may charge, receive and recover fees for agricultural research or basic veterinary research undertaken on behalf of any person, firm, institution or agency, and for services, courses, seminars, lectures and demonstrations provided or organised by it. They can be charged fees for that vast range of things. No fee may be charged in respect of any advice given by the authority in response to a request from the Minister under section 21. Section 21 says:
The Authority shall advise the Minister on any matter relating to agricultural education, advice or research or to basic veterinary research on which its views are requested by the Minister.

No fees may be charged for that. All the research functions are going to An Foras under the new Bill. The matter becomes clearer as Deputy Bruton continues. “Any facilities, assistance or courses of instruction that may be provided by the authority under section 14 or 16”—we can go back to those. Section 14 says the authority shall provide courses in agriculture for the purpose of implementing directives of the European Economic Community when requested to do so by the Minister. Section 16 says that the authority shall maintain close liaison and co-operate as may be necessary with the Minister and other agencies in the operation of such schemes and facilities for agricultural development as may be administered by them, and provide such facilities and assistance as the Minister may require for the purpose of implementing directives of the European Economic Community. What the deletion of the whole section amounts to really, in my opinion, is the deletion of the provision for the collection of fees by AnCOT which is not a fee-collecting body. An Foras is the research body and we are talking about veterinary and general research and all that goes with it, seminars, lectures, demonstrations and so on.

I should like to pursue the issue in relation to section 48 (3) and 48 (4) of the old Act which are also being removed. This says that the grant by the State to the authority—now AnCOT—shall not be less in real terms than the total amount provided by the Oireachtas in the financial year immediately preceding the date of the establishment of the authority in respect of the activities of the authority in the financial year to which the grant relates. There is a guarantee in the old Act that the finance provided by the Oireachtas to AnCOT shall not be reduced. I would like to know why that guarantee is now being removed.

I recall, when the earlier Bill was going through the House, asking the Minister then, if my memory is correct, if it was not a poor guarantee for the future of the advisory services that the Minister should say that the provision shall be no less than it is in this year when what we should be envisaging, as I have already being saying in relation to other sections, is a rapidly changing and growing advisory service, a service that, as I have also being saying, has been changing in nature, a service that at this moment contains a factor consisting of the voluntary payment of fees by farmers for certain services rendered, altering at this moment the traditional texture of the advisory services in incorporating that very useful factor voluntarily called in to existence by the farmers. It was the farmers themselves and their co-operatives who produced this very desirable development in agricultural work.

Sections 48 (3) and 48 (4) envisages a position of total lack of movement, that the old order continue unchanged. I have been endeavouring to get Deputy Bruton, and others, to accept the point that this is not the case. The old order is changing in front of our eyes. To enshrine it in legislation, as my predecessor did, would be to accept that things are not going to change themselves. This is not so and I would not wish to legislate in a manner that would accept a proposition I do not accept.

I agree with the Minister to a certain extent, that the part of the previous Act which guaranteed that it would not be reduced may have indicated a static performance but at least it was a guarantee. Many people fear that the finance available to the services may be cut back and there is nothing here to guarantee any level of spending in the services.
I do not think the Bill should incorporate that guarantee because to include it would be to restrict one's own freedom of movement.
It is only one's freedom of movement that is restricted by section 48.

I do not think it would be practical politics, and this is a political assembly, for any Minister for Agriculture to deliberately or otherwise run down the advisory services precisely because it is in agricultural development that——
The Minister could be arranging to get money from other sources compulsorily and, thereby, run down his own contribution.
That could be. We have an example at present of people providing money from other sources. That is in operation at present. It is a good thing and I am sure Deputy Bruton agrees with it.
As long as it is voluntary.

There is a feeling at present that the co-ops and others will have to provide the service and that this may give the opportunity to some administration to cut back and pay less for the services. The guarantee that was there was not great but it was one which ensured that the amount would not cut back. If co-ops and others are expected to provide the kind of advisory service that is necessary there is the possibility that the Government and the comhairle may rely on that source and give less themselves.

There is also the possibility that the Government may decide that the idea of farmers providing money for research, education and advice was a good thing. They may decide that it is very good when done voluntarily but even better if farmers could be compelled to do so by the Government. If the Government could get £30 million from the farmers direct for advice, education and research they might reduce the amount being provided by way of grant under section 48. That is what the Government have in mind. They are proposing to introduce a levy to finance these services.
I must again ask the Deputy not to get on to that. We have been long enough on this matter without having another argument on that score.

The Government propose to include a levy and to remove a guarantee that the grants from the Exchequer to the comhairle may not be reduced. There is a connection between the two because the Government hope that by introducing the levy they will not have to provide any grant for the comhairle.
We cannot discuss taxation on this section. The Deputy can discuss the section without referring to taxation.
I am discussing the removal of a guarantee that State funds to the comhairle will not fall below the level they were at when section 48 of the old Act was introduced.
In doing that the Deputy is trying to get around a ruling of the Chair.

If a levy is to be introduced to provide £30 million per year for agricultural advice, research and education the State will not have to provide any money apart from the levy because the levy will take it in. The removal of this guarantee is facilitating the introduction of a levy.
I have asked the Deputy to obey the Chair on several occasions. We cannot discuss the levy today but the Deputy may do so tomorrow.

I am not discussing the levy; I am referring to section 48 (4) of the old Act which gave a guarantee that a certain amount of money would be provided by the State. That guarantee is being removed and that must facilitate having these services funded in some other way. The removal of the guarantee contained in section 48 is objectionable because, unintentional or otherwise—I am happy to believe it was unintentional because the Bill was drafted long before there was any thought of a levy—it facilitates the introduction of a levy.

SECTION 6.
Question proposed: “That section 6 stand part of the Bill.”

This section relates to the dissolution of the National Agricultural Authority. The National Agricultural Authority was set up by the previous Government to achieve a purpose which we believed to be right: to unify agricultural education, research and advice in the one authority which would direct all of them for the common objective of increased agricultural production and increased incomes on the land. We must object very strongly to the dissolution of a body which had that purpose.

We are now putting forward in an amendment to this Bill an alternative method to achieve the same object as was intended by setting up the National Agricultural Authority. I believe the setting up of the National Agricultural Authority was the best way to do this job because it brought all three services together under one authority. I object to section 6 because it is undoing that good work.

Deputy Bruton and the House know that I disagree profoundly with him on this fundamental matter, the independence of our research arm in agriculture. All the objective scientific analyses of this problem have been done by the OECD and by other objective people with no particular axe of their own to grind. I have not any axe to grind. All kinds of things have been attributed to me and I can only say that they are not correct. My only wish is to see An Foras Talúntais continue its present excellent work and maintain its high international position rather than be confronted with the inevitability of running down through the dissolution that awaited it in the passage of the old Act. I remember during the Committee Stage of the older Bill that only two Deputies on the Government side spoke on this matter and they both spoke against the motion on the amalgamation of research, advice and training.

I believe the ground has been covered so exhaustively on this issue that there is not much point in going very much further on it this evening. I believe that research should not be separated from advice and education because they all have the same objective: helping farmers to increase production and helping to increase the efficiency of the processing section of our economy so far as food is concerned.

This is not the type of research which is being carried out in the Agricultural Institute. It is research for the sake of agriculture. Advice and education for the sake of agriculture is not the type of research that is carried out in a university which, rightly, has complete academic freedom and is not directed to the service of any particular interest in the economy, any social political or economic interest. It is free from all of those.

MainHeading.P: The Agricultural Institute was set up separate from the universities with the purpose of being more directly related to the needs of the economy and agriculture than the work of the universities, which was concerned with other criteria, the general advancement of learning, truth and so forth. Other criteria will also be used in universities so long as there is academic freedom. That is fine for universities. But for an agricultural institute which is separate from universities, and was set up separate from them for a particular purpose, the same criteria of academic freedom in relation to research do not apply, because it is a different institution with a different purpose. I do not have any violent views about the issue and I am not anxious to get involved in an argument with the Minister about it. I want to report my view of the issue that it would have been better if the Minister had allowed the three institutions to continue together. He has decided otherwise. Although we may object we must for the time being accept the consequences of his decision.

Speaker.P: Amendments Nos. 11 and 21 are related and may be discussed together.
I move amendment No. 11:
In page 5, before section 10, to insert a new section as follows:
“10.—Section 12 of the Act of 1977 is hereby amended by the addition of the following subsections:

(3) Courses or lectures to be provided in agriculture under subsection (1) of this section may include preventive veterinary medicine, and the Authority shall make arrangements to ensure that qualified persons are available to provide such courses or lectures insofar as they concern preventive veterinary medicine.

MainHeading.P: (4) The Authority shall provide courses and lectures specially designed for employed farm workers if, in respect of any part of the country it is satisfied that employed farm workers are not being adequately catered for in existing courses and lectures provided on a general basis'.”.

The purpose of these amendments is to request the comhairle to do work which they might not otherwise do. It is work which we believe would be of great value. The amendments are not intended to be controversial and I do not suggest that the Minister is likely to disagree with the sentiments expressed. The question is whether we need to specify that these things need to be done.

We are seeking in amendment No. 11 to change the provisions of section 12 of the old Act relating to the educational functions of the comhairle. We are proposing that the comhairle should be allowed to run courses or lectures in agriculture which would include preventive veterinary medicine and that they should make arrangements to ensure that qualified persons are available to provide such courses or lectures. I believe preventive veterinary medicine is a very important part of agriculture and to the best of my knowledge there are not any veterinary surgeons on the staff of the county committees of agriculture or on the advisory arm of AnCOT. This is regrettable.

I attended a 100-hour course under Directive 161. Two lectures were given by veterinary surgeons who were brought in from the district veterinary office. One felt that this was a concession and was not really part of the course. I believe preventive veterinary medicine is an integral part of agriculture and AnCOT have a clear mandate to provide these courses. The Minister may say that the district veterinary offices are equipped to provide farmers with any information they may want on veterinary matters and that they can deal with the issue. I would not agree with that because the district veterinary office staff are not educators or trainers. Their functions are basically administrative and they are not equipped to spend a large part of their time giving courses to farmers on veterinary matters. Neither is the farmer's veterinary surgeon equipped to do this because he is too busy. He is concerned with curing disease and, while he is professionally concerned with the prevention of disease, he has not the time to become involved in educating farmers about preventive veterinary medicine. Prevention is better than cure and effective prevention requires knowledge and information. This is true not simply in the context of brucellosis and turberculosis eradication but in the entire area of agriculture. An agricultural training or educational authority which does not have a specific mandate to deal with preventive veterinary medicine has not a complete mandate. I hope the Minister will be able to accept this point.

Amendment No. 21 also concerns preventive veterinary medicine and the advisory aspect of the work. Advisers should be in a position to obtain advice from specialists on veterinary matters. There might be some objection from some veterinary surgeons. They may not want to see any State agency becoming involved in giving veterinary advice to farmers and may say that they, as private practitioners, are the only people who should do this. I do not think any profession operating privately should have a monopoly on an important matter such as this.
The last part of amendment No. 11 states:

(4) The Authority shall provide courses and lectures specially designed for employed farm workers if, in respect of any part of the country it is satisfied that employed farm workers are not being adequately catered for in existing courses and lectures provided on a general basis.

My impression is that the vast bulk of courses, if not the entirety, are provided for farmers or their sons and little or nothing is being done to improve the professional competence of the employed farm worker. With modern trends in farming, particularly in certain lines of production like cereals, the employed farm worker is a very important and highly skilled man who should, and in many cases does, command a high wage. It should be made quite clear to the authority that they have a duty to provide courses for employed farm workers and not just for farmers and they should ensure that the courses are suitable for such workers. In some cases there would be a need to change the courses to suit farm workers. They are not free at the same times of the day as farmers, who are their own bosses and can make themselves free. No compensation has to be given for their absence. They are doing it on their own time. That does not apply to farm workers. If one is to get farm workers involved in agricultural education in a way in which they are not involved at present special provision must be made by the authority. Amendment No. 11 is not requiring the authority to provide special courses for farm workers in every county but rather to provide them in any county where it is satisfied they are not adequately catered for by existing courses. That does not tie the authority down. It is requiring them to take whatever steps are needed. It is a constructive and useful amendment and one which I hope the Minister will accept.
The second part of amendment No. 21—I do not know how all these amendments were put in together——

Speaker.P: The Chair wonders sometimes too. They are related.
I do not question the Chair. They are diverse.
This amendment requires that:

In the exercise of these functions the Authority shall devote special attention to those farm families and others engaged in agriculture whose economic performance falls furthest below the economic potential of the resources (land and otherwise) available to them.

MainHeading.P: The purpose of inserting the amendment is that it is all too easy for people involved in advice and education to spend the vast amount of their time dealing with 10 or 15 per cent of farmers who are most efficient. These are the people who come to the advice centre looking for advice. If you are an adviser and you visit their farms you are as likely to learn something as you are to impart advice. An adviser who has been trained in agriculture in a university is naturally interested in the type of work the best farmers are doing. The temptation is there for them to spend much more of their time with such farmers than they should. This amendment requires the authority to do the opposite and give special attention to those farmers who are less efficient, particularly small farmers who are in greatest need. That is a sensible requirement to have in the Bill.

The amendment is concerned with cases where economic performance falls furthest below the economic potential either of the farm, the farmer or the land. There are great differences in performance of farms in different parts of the country. There are some counties where land of the same productive capacity is yielding three times as much as it does in other counties. The resources of the advisory and education service should be concentrated in those areas where performance is falling furthest below potential. If that means diverting them away from areas where there is already high performance, so be it. If such a provision is not included in the Bill the authority will leave staff as they are in the counties where they are and will pay no attention to the fact that there are some parts of the country which could achieve a great deal more if they got special attention. Such a provision would require the authority to take account of where need is greatest and to allocate resources to those areas.

Part 3 of the amendment deals with an entirely different issue. It concerns the farm home management service which consists mainly of women advisers although there is no requirement as to the sex of the adviser. They advise farmers' wives on how to make arrangements for the housing of the family, management of the home, clothing of the children, food, nutrition and so on. This advice is only available to farming families. At the time when this service was initiated the need for such assistance was probably greatest in the agricultural section of our community. Things have changed since that time. In my constituency most farmers now have a sufficient income and their wives have sufficient education to enable them to manage a home, maintenance, clothing, textiles and so on as well as any other section of the community with similar incomes.

It is not fair that this service should be exclusively confined to farmers' wives. Advice about home management, clothing and textiles, food and nutrition and so on would be very valuable to deprived families living in towns. I know from my work in the Department of Education that one of the reasons why there are so many social problems and malnutrition in places such as Seán MacDermott Street and also among old age pensioners is not that they have insufficient income, although some of them have, but that they are not sufficiently advised on how to use it in managing their homes, buying the right food and ensuring that they have a proper diet. In the farm home management service there are people specifically qualified to give advice on these matters and yet they may only give it to farmers' wives. They cannot give it to the people in Seán MacDermott Street or anywhere else. There is a greater need for the work of home management advisers in deprived areas of the city centre than there is among farmers' wives in my constituency. They attend 100-hour courses and receive substantial payments to do so. The need for such advice and courses, subsidised or otherwise, is greater among many non-farm families both urban and rural.

I am sure the Minister will agree that, no matter how prosperous a parish may be agriculturally or industrially, there are always a minority of families who cannot cope. Perhaps the father is gone away or the mother is an alcoholic. Unless they are farmers they cannot get the advice of the home management service. That is wrong. It should be possible for the service to help such people. My amendment is proposing that, by arrangement with the appropriate health board, they may make provision for the giving of such advice to needy families of a non-agricultural or non-rural background. It is left open. The authority may make such arrangements but they are not required by this amendment to do so. It is merely leaving it open to them to make such arrangements by agreement with the health boards. Many health board would welcome having available to them the staff of the farm home management service to give advice on home management matters to some people, for instance, those in receipt of supplementary welfare allowances. Those people would be able to make far better use of that money if they had advice of the sort I have mentioned from this service which is at present confined to farmers. I hope the Minister will be able to accept the amendment.

Speaker.P: In my opinion, the amendments concerning the provision of veterinary advice are not necessary, although I agree with much of what the Deputy said about dissemination of sensible veterinary knowledge in the preventive sense among stock farmers generally. In the context of animal disease we have reason to exercise particular care not only with regard to the major infectious diseases such as brucellosis and TB but also with regard to sources of serious loss to the country such as calf and lamb mortality and animal mortality generally, a great deal of which I believe is avoidable. I think calf mortality is in the region of 10 per cent. It is far too high and it amounts to an enormous loss each year.

MainHeading.P: There is no getting away from the fact that the propagation of knowledge about basic hygiene and basic attention to animals before and after birth is very important. I still regard the amendment as unnecessary in view of the fact that lectures, instructions and seminars can be provided by the present arrangement and are provided. In the future I believe that the Department of Agriculture will assist and encourage in the expansion of our efforts in the propagation of this kind of knowledge, in particular with regard to prevention of losses of young lambs, calves and pigs. I believe that the motivation of the Deputies is right but I do not think the introduction of the special amendment is necessary having regard to the fact that the facility is there already.

Speaker.P: AnCOT do not have that facility.

The capacity of a committee to provide lectures is there. Lectures of this kind should be given by a veterinary surgeon and they are given. I remember attending some such lectures myself many years ago. I acknowledge the need to expand this aspect of the advisory services.
The advisory services do not employ veterinary surgeons.
That is so.
Does the Minister think they should employ veterinary surgeons?

I am not satisfied that the employment of veterinary staff by AnCOT as well as by the Department would be desirable. The more informal arrangements that the individual committees have at the moment and had in the past—and there is no reason why they should not have them in the future—preclude the necessity for the appointment of specialist vets whose main daily work would not be in the lecturing and instruction area. Many of the people who would benefit from such instruction would be engaged in their ordinary daily work. I am talking about the propagation of information and knowledge and, as an example, I took the conservation of young livestock.

Ideally this would be conveyed to groups of farmers in a series of lectures. I presume these lectures would be delivered in short weekend courses or in evening courses and at winter schools. They present no problem. They are being done but possibly they could be done to a greater extent. The same applies to the special provision made in the part of the Deputy's amendment concerning the provision of special facilities for people employed on farms. These facilities exist at present.
Where?
With the committees.
They do not exist. They may in theory but not in practice.
There is no reason I am aware of why they should not exist.
I was on a course and there was not a single farm worker on it.
There are certain courses where they can be included but they are definitely excluded from some courses.

I would be very disturbed if that were so. I should like substantiation of the exclusion of any kind of farm people from lectures provided by the committees of agriculture. If that were so I would certainly take it up with the committee in question. It is not any part of their business to exclude people from the farming sector, regardless of which part, from the facilities they provide for a large section of the population.
They are excluded from some of the EEC courses.
Is the Minister satisfied that farm workers are getting enough attention?

More could be done. They are a new breed of workers now. They are more skilled and better paid than was the case. A lot of the time of men working with tillage farmers is taken up with machinery and they would need to be competent in the management of that machinery. The same applies to stockmen—a high degree of stockmanship is obviously necessary. Farm workers who have competence in these departments, and in regard to dairy cattle and sheep, can command incomes far above the standard wage, which is not in my opinion high enough for the type of worker we require in farming at present. The need is so obvious that there is no necessity to have a provision saying that you must do certain things.

MainHeading.P: On the question of the provision of farm home guidance, not being familiar with the origins of this service, which originated in the old days of the poultry instructresses, in the average farmyard nowadays poultry has disappeared completely. In the old days a small flock of poultry was kept for the use of the household. That day has gone and poultry raising has become a specialised industry.

I do not deny that there are cases such as Deputy Bruton spoke of in rural communities with problems of a social kind. There are people who are not deriving proper livelihoods from farming and such people, one cannot deny, require assistance. However, the resources of committees of agriculture and AnCOT will always be fully taken up within their own spheres of operations, that is among people who work on the land, whether as farmers or farmer workers. I would therefore view with concern the extension of that service in the way Deputy Bruton spoke of—the extension of these forms of assistance to urban people who have no relation with agriculture. If you did that the service would cease to be a farm home guidance scheme.

Speaker.P: Does the Minister not agree there is a greater need for this sort of service among deprived people rather than among farmers?

Every Deputy knows, after a weekend working in his constituency, that a certain fraction of old people, who because of some personal deficiency or personal misfortune, are living in undesirable circumstances and it would be well if a helping hand could be given to such people, but it is not within the ambit of AnCOT to provide this assistance. I am sure we would all like to see such assistance given, and there is nothing to stop us, as private persons, from providing that assistance from the means available to us. Frankly I do not think we could do it in the way suggested because it would become a huge service with little or no connection with farming.
I raised a point about farms whose economic performances have not been good from the point of view of the resources available to them.

This has been a matter of concern to some of the more active committees of agriculture. The advisers themselves have gone to such places as creameries, where farmers can be met in large numbers, to find out about farmers whom the advisers have never met before but whom they could help, and frequently do. There are quite a substantial number of farmers who do not make any worth-while use of the advisory services or have continued resort to our advisory services. There is no contention about this. However, the overall purpose of the Bill is to deal with the parcel of problems concerned with farm advice and instruction, to put these problems into the hands of the comhairle and to give the comhairle the maximum amount of freedom of action.

The comhairle will have it within their power to decide how important these problems are and how much effort they should put into solving them. For instance, there are the special needs of the western area which will have to be dealt with. I do not believe that at this juncture legislation should contain any special references to particular farmers. It will be for the comhairle to determine these things in consultation with the Minister for Agriculture of the day.

I support the amendment which deals with a side of agriculture neglected for many years. The county committees of agriculture who are operating the services at the moment have made some attempts to bring veterinary advice to farmers but they have been finding quite a lot of difficulties. The Minister mentioned a 10 per cent fatality rate in calves and lambs. I think it is considerably higher in certain cases.
It is higher in lambs.

We must accept that the days of the big price increases have nearly gone and that we now must get down to efficiency and good husbandry. The amendment deals with matters which have not been looked after for years. It is my belief that the veterinary profession can play a very important role here. It will be in everybody's interest to have professional advice made available. It is hard to believe that practitioners will provide such a service and I suggest seriously that the new authority should provide such advice. Fatalities in calves and lambs can be brought down quite easily. It is not the time of calving or lambing that is important but the time immediately preceding that period. Housing is important, medicines are important. As this is an area in which effective and worth-while advances can be made, I would ask the Minister to consider the amendment.

The Minister referred to the role of farm home management advisors. In Wexford we have never told the advisors that they should only deal with farm homes. We have broadened the service and I think it is right that we should. We may be breaking the rules but farmhouse holidays are important in Wexford with our 130-mile coastline. The people who come from all over the world to our resorts are important to us. We have always believed that the advice should be given to all those who require it. I know that the Minister comes from a different county with different needs. The need is there and it is a good development in a county. We run courses of lectures and everybody is entitled to attend them.

This amendment is very important. People are learning the hard way that they must keep receipts of their losses. I appeal to the Minister to make some provision to allow the authority to use qualified personnel in order to improve the situation.

In some cases farm workers may become involved in these courses, but the committees are not doing enough to design courses to attract farm workers. I am sure the Minister will agree that farm workers are not as freely available to attend courses as farmers. A farmer may be able to attend a course which involves an absence of two or three days a week but a farm worker may not, particularly if he is hoping to move to more lucrative employment. His employer will not facilitate him if he thinks he will lose him. There is a need to make special provision for farm workers and the amendment would be a valuable move in this direction. It does not require the provision of courses for farm workers everywhere, only where adequate provision is not being made.

I am not happy with the Minister's answer in relation to preventive veternary advice. I know it is possible for the county committees to give preventive veterinary advice but they have not got the staff to do it. There is not a single veterinarian employed by the advisory service anywhere in the country. The only way they can give advice is by getting members of the district veterinary office to attend a course on a particular night. People may well need advice in the middle of the day. The only way in which they can get preventive advice is by ringing their veterinarian. If he calls he will have to be paid a substantial fee for his advice. Why should farmers have to pay for advice when it could be provided by an agricultural advisory service.
The Deputy's predecessor knew that the man had to be paid.

If their mandate were extended AnCOT could pay him. It would be mainly for advice in relation to preventive matters. As AnCOT will have specialist advisors, why not have veterinary surgeons amongst them.
I am also unhappy with the Minister's attitude to farm home management advisers. The need for home management advice is greater amongst deprived non-farm families than it is amongst farm families.
It ceases to be a farm problem.

The farm home management service is the only group of people who are specifically qualified in home management. The health boards have social workers but they are not concerned with home management. Many deprived families need the type of advice which the farm home management service provide. The provision of advice to deprived families would eliminate many problems such as malnutrition. We have been told that there is malnutrition amongst children in many schools because their mothers do not know how to prepare proper breakfasts for them. Many children go to school without a proper breakfast. Their parents can afford to buy food but they give it to them at the wrong time of day or spend it on alcoholic beverages. When food is provided for these children it is usually the wrong type of food. The farm home management service is the only State service that is competent to give advice on nutrition. It is a pity that this service is confined to giving advice where it is least needed. I agree with the Minister that it would not be a farm home management service if it was extended in this way but that is no reason for not extending it. The staff members are there; but are being paid by the State and are not being used in the most effective way.

I hope the Minister will consider the amendment. I should also like the Minister to assure the House that there will be movement of staff under AnCOT to those parts of the country where economic performance is falling short of its potential.
Progress reported; Committee to sit again.
